root:
:''There is also an [[asteroid]] called [[55 Pandora]].'' <!-- Scroll down to edit the contents of this page. Additional parameters for this template are available at [[Template:Infobox Planet]]. --> Infobox Planet name = Pandora image = [[Image:Pandora PIA07632.jpg|300px]] caption = Pandora, as imaged by Cassini bgcolour = #a0ffa0 discovery = yes discoverer = [[Stewart A. Collins|Collins]], [[Voyager 1]] discovered = October, 1980 orbit_ref =ref name="Spitale2006"{{cite journal | author= Spitale, J. N.; ''et al.''| title= ''The orbits of Saturn's small satellites derived from combined historic and ''Cassini'' imaging observations''| journal= The Astronomical Journal| year= 2006| volume= 132 | issue=2 | pages= 692–710 | url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/article/1538-3881/132/2/692/205235.html | doi= 10.1086/505206 }}</ref> epoch = December 31, 2003 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2453005.5) semimajor = 141,720 ± 10 km eccentricity = 0.0042 period = 0.628504213 d inclination = 0.050 ± 0.004° to Saturn's equator satellite_of = [[Saturn]] physical_characteristics = yes dimensions = 103×80×64 kmref name="Porco2006"{{cite journal | author= [[Carolyn C. Porco|Porco, C. C.]]; ''et al.''| title= ''Physical Characteristics and Possible Accretionary Origins for Saturn's Small Satellites''| journal= Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society| year= 2006| volume= 37| pages= 768| url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2006/pdf/2289.pdf}}</ref> mean_radius = 40.3 ± 2.2 kmref name="Porco2006" surface_area = ~21,000 km² volume = ~270,000 km³ mass = 1.356 ± 0.022 e17 [[kilogram|kg]]ref name="Spitale2006" density = 0.49 ± 0.08 g/cm³ surface_grav = 0.0034 [[Acceleration|m/s<sup>2</sup>]] escape_velocity = ~0.019 km/s rotation = [[synchronous rotation|synchronous]] axial_tilt = zero albedo = 0.6 single_temperature = ~78 K
'''Pandora''' (pronEngpænˈdɔərə respellpanDOHRə, or as in Greek ''Πανδώρα)'' is an [[inner satellite]] of [[Saturn]]. It was discovered in 1980 from photos taken by the ''[[Voyager 1]]'' probe, and was provisionally designated '''nowrapS/1980 S 26'''.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03500/03532.html IAUC 3532: ''Satellites of Saturn''] October 31, 1980 (discovery)</ref> In late 1985 it was officially named after [[Pandora]] from [[Greek mythology]].ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/04100/04157.html IAUC 4157: ''Satellites of Saturn and Pluto''] January 3, 1986 (naming the moon)</ref> It is also designated as '''nowrapSaturn XVII'''.ref name="Gazetteer"{{cite web | title = Planet and Satellite Names and Discoverers | work = Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature | publisher = USGS Astrogeology | date = July 21, 2006 | url = http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/append7.html | accessdate = 2006-08-07 }}</ref>
Pandora is the outer [[shepherd satellite]] of the [[Rings of Saturn#F Ring|F Ring]]. It is more heavily cratered than nearby [[Prometheus (moon)|Prometheus]], and has at least two large craters 30 km in diameter.ref[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Sat_Pandora NASA JPL Solar System Exploration: Saturn: Moons: Pandora]</ref>
The orbit of Pandora appears to be chaotic, as a consequence of a [[orbital resonance #Types of resonance|mean motion resonance]] with Prometheus. The most appreciable changes in their orbits occur approximately every 6.2 years,ref name="Spitale2006" when the [[periapsis]] of Pandora lines up with the [[apoapsis]] of Prometheus and the moons approach to within about 1,400 km. Pandora also has a 3:2 mean-motion resonance with [[Mimas (moon)|Mimas]].ref name="Spitale2006"
From its very low density and relatively high [[albedo]], it seems likely that Pandora is a very porous icy body. There is a lot of uncertainty in these values, however, so this remains to be confirmed.
The [[2009]] movie [[Avatar]] takes place on a fictive moon called Pandora allegedly located in the [[Alpha Centauri]] star systemrefhttp://james-camerons-avatar.wikia.com/wiki/Pandora</ref>. ==Gallery== gallery widths="240px" heights="240px" Image:Pandora moon.jpg|''[[Voyager 2]]'' image of Pandora. Image:Pandora - PIA07570.jpg|Pandora as seen from the [[Cassini probe]] in 2005; the rings of Saturn are in the background. </gallery>
